Understanding the Process of Merging Views

Views may be merged for a variety of reasons. For example, if both maintenance and new development for a software product need to occur in parallel, a separate view is often created to store each set of source code files. If you fix some defects in the maintenance view, you may need to merge items from that view into the new development view so that the next release of your product does not have those defects.

You can compare and merge any two project views if those views are in the same server configuration. However, you can merge only items that correspond (that is, have a common ancestor), even though that ancestor may not be in either of the views you are comparing or merging. Usually you do not compare or merge two views that have few or no corresponding items in common.

The application allows you to compare and merge views:

  • On the Windows client, by using the viewmerge command or by working with the View Comparison utility.

  • On the Cross-Platform client, by using View Manager as a command line utility or as an application with a graphical interface.

 

Although two views can be merged in different ways, the basic steps involved in a merge are similar.

To compare and merge views:

  1. From the main baseline view, create a new view for maintenance development.

  2. Name the view and give it an appropriate name and description.

  3. Permit items to branch in the new view and select Branch all.

  4. Select a new working folder for the view.

  5. Select a view configuration based on a specific date and time, label, or promotion state.

  6. Check all of your bug fixes into the new maintenance view.

  7. Then, to merge file changes in the maintenance view into the mainline view, use the command line interface or the appropriate utility.
